It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is characterized by its distinctive, milky sap. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 3 meters. Its leaves are alternate, simple, and often have a waxy texture. Acampe nyassana produces small, clustered flowers that are usually greenish-yellow in color.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acampe nyassana is primarily native to eastern and southern Africa, including countries such as Tanzania, Kenya, Uganda, and Zambia. It is commonly found in woodland and savanna habitats, often growing in areas with well-drained soils. The plant is adapted to the tropical and subtropical climates of these regions, thriving in both dry and wet seasons. It is an important component of the local flora and is sometimes used in traditional medicine. Its distribution is closely linked to the natural vegetation patterns of the African continent.
